title: Mexican Grand Prix 2019: What time does the F1 race start on Sunday, what TV channel is it on and what are the latest odds?
text:
What is it?

The 2019 Mexican Grand Prix, the 18th race of the 2019 Formula One season.

When is it?

The first two practice sessions take place on Friday October 25 with third and final practice and qualifying running on Saturday October 26. The Grand Prix itself is on Sunday October 27.

What time does it start?

Qualifying starts at 7pm BST and the race starts at 7.10pm GMT. Remember, the clocks go back one hour on Sunday morning.

What TV channel is it on?

Sky Sports F1 have exclusive coverage rights in the UK this year and indeed for the next few. Their qualifying coverage begins at 6pm BST and their race program starts at 5.30pm GMT.

Channel 4 have highlights for this round, too. Their qualifying coverage begins at 10.45pm BST on Sunday, with race highlights starting at 11pm GMT on Sunday.

You can also keep up to date throughout the race with Luke Slater right here at Telegraph Sport.

Watch the Mexican Grand Prix through Now TV for £9.99.

What do we know about the Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez?

Circuit length: 4.304km

4.304km First grand prix: 1963

1963 Laps: 71

71 Race distance: 305.354km

305.354km Race lap record: 1.18.741 (Valtteri Bottas, 2018)

1.18.741 (Valtteri Bottas, 2018) 2018 winner: Max Verstappen, Red Bull

Max Verstappen, Red Bull Number of corners: 17

17 Overtaking chances: At the end of the long pit straight is the best chance, as it's one of the biggest braking zones on the circuit. Failing that, going into the tight turn four also presents an opportunity. However, the middle and end of the lap is quite tight and twisty and following closely is difficult. Passing is, naturally, even more difficult.

What is our prediction?

For the past couple of years, Red Bull have been the quickest at this track in both qualifying and race trim but since returning from the summer break, the Milton Keynes-based team have fallen a bit behind Ferrari and Mercedes and I find it difficult to see them overhauling both teams enough to claim pole position.
